@yzheng-hortonworks this is specific to using TD connectors. We don't have infrastructure to invoke TD connector during the UT and IT.
Will commit
Instead of creating a dependency on Hadoop 2.8, we can just copy the same filter (it's just one class for code and one class for tests). I would prefer to avoid dependency on Hadoop 2.8

As I had predicted quite some time back, UI specific code has started creeping into our backend (deja-vu @sriksun ? :stuck_out_tongue: ).  In general, I don't like the idea of UI only concerns creeping in REST services, such code are better handled by UI specific frameworks. We already have several commands just for UI and it keeps growing. 

May be we should just switch to a more robust UI framework instead of giving one solution at a time and building everything on our own.

Also, this is not the best way to implement CSRF protection. The most recommended way to implement CSRF is the _Synchronizer (CSRF) Tokens_. Mechanisms like above are not safe against plugin vulnerabilities like [this ](http://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/441014/30/0/threaded)
May be I overlooked something obvious, but how is the filter distinguishing between requests from UI / other API calls?

> > As I had predicted quite some time back, UI specific code has started creeping into our backend (deja-vu @sriksun ?  ). In general, I don't like the idea of UI only concerns creeping in REST services, such code are better handled by UI specific frameworks.

Not sure how a UI specific framework alone be useful in this case for not adding this filter - There is nothing that prevents a user to have a UI that call the REST api without going through your UI framework

> > May be I overlooked something obvious, but how is the filter distinguishing between requests from UI / other API calls?

In RestCsrfPreventionFilter, they only perform CSRF check if the request is from the browser.

> > Instead of creating a dependency on Hadoop 2.8, we can just copy the same filter (it's just one class for code and one class for tests). I would prefer to avoid dependency on Hadoop 2.8

Thanks for bringing this up, @ajayyadava . @vrangan and I had a discussion on this before. Because RestCsrfPreventionFilter can be shared among all Hadoop components, including hive, oozie, hbase, etc., we think it is better to leave the implementation and improvements to this class, instead of reinventing the wheel. Let us know your opinion.

> > Also, this is not the best way to implement CSRF protection. The most recommended way to implement CSRF is the Synchronizer (CSRF) Tokens. Mechanisms like above are not safe against plugin vulnerabilities like this

Yes, adding synchronizer tokens would definitely make the filter stronger. @vrangan: Do you know if Hadoop team has this plan to improve RestCsrfPreventionFilter? Thank you.

> Not sure how a UI specific framework alone be useful in this case for not adding this filter - There is nothing that prevents a user to have a UI that call the REST api without going through your UI framework

If user is using his own UI framework, then security concerns of UI are also his concern and not of the REST API. It will be same for other UI concerns like cookie management etc. They make sense only for UI client and should be part of UI and not REST API. The reason that we have to put them in REST API is because our UI can not handle it on its own.

> In RestCsrfPreventionFilter, they only perform CSRF check if the request is from the browser.

From the hadoop patch it seems to me that once this is enabled, it will act on all clients (including cli) and not just UI. From the patch:

> Enabling this filter on an endpoint results in the requirement of all client to send a particular (configurable) HTTP header with every request.

I suspect that the filter itself doesn't distinguish the requests from different clients but relies on enabling it only on endpoints specific to UI and hence my question.

> Because RestCsrfPreventionFilter can be shared among all Hadoop components, including hive, oozie, hbase, etc., we think it is better to leave the implementation and improvements to this class, instead of reinventing the wheel. 

If we were already on Hadoop 2.8 then I would have also agreed. However, currently I am of the opinion that is better to "copy the wheel" and allow existing falcon users to use this feature without requiring them to upgrade to next version of Hadoop.

@yzheng-hortonworks Yes that is what I was expecting to see in the patch but I couldn't find. I was looking only at the issue that you provided in the JIRA HADOOP-12691 and that doesn't contain this code. Turns out, it is part of the related JIRA HADOOP-12758. Thanks I will review again.

Ok. Thank you @ajayyadava . I have forked RestCsrfPreventionFilter from Hadoop 2.8.0 and also improved code structure. Going to add options in startup.properties for custom header and browser user agent.
+1 for the fix. The jenkins failures are unrelated. So will commit the patch soon.

Added configuration properties to allow custom header and browser agent. Also fixed checkstyle errors in Hadoop 2.8.0 RestCsrfPreventionFilter. Tested with CSRF filter enabled and custom header "FALCON-CSRF-FILTER" that 1) GET methods always work; 2) POST/DELETE methods will be accepted only if the user provides the correct custom header (See pictures in description); 3) Falcon CLI works well. @ajayyadava  Could you review? Thank you!

I know you plan to open a separate documentation JIRA. Please also open one to disable post-processing for Import/Export, if you are not comfortable making the changes.

Don't merge this before the above one gets merged.

No challenges for UT will add them too in the current classes.
The build has gone through fine. Merging.

Thanks

Closing in favor of https://github.com/apache/falcon/pull/249

This patch has been tested end2end to gaurantee data integrity in graphDB when upgrading from 0.9 to 0.10

@PraveenAdlakha This is huge! Thank you for working on it. Apart from some minor nits the patch looks good to me. However, it will be nice if you can confirm the following as I haven't been able to verify them.
1. There is no intended/unintended change in existing CLI functionality. It will be nice to test a couple of error cases and happy scenarios.
2. All commands in CLI are now also available in shell and there is no change in the behavior of the commands(except the syntax of course)

Look forward to the docs(I noticed you have already created another JIRA for that).
+1 apart from the point on HDFSServerConfigs.
video link : http://showterm.io/845935d36f61f897cbf7a
I have tested the happy scenarios for shell and some users have used it to run there pipeline from fresh and its working fine.Let me know incase there are any concerns.
:+1: LGTM. Will commit tomorrow unless someone expresses any concerns.

One minor nit - we have many different scripting solutions in the product.   A few python and shell scripts.   May be we add a dependency on Jython and convert all scripts to Python scripts compatible with Jython also and can have consistency and ease.

We currently do package groovy but given lots of existing python files, it maybe faster to just use Jython dependency as a core dependency (and use the version used in Pig which has been vetted for any security vulnerabilities known thus far).

Will start a Discuss thread on this

I think the option to integrate the Hadoop 2.8 code into the filter here with the config options is good to provide the basic CsrfProtection wihtout having hadoop 2.8 dependencies.  

+1 for the options also
+1 LGTM
